message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-alanyl-D-alanine residues on the peptidoglycan cell wall precursor molecules. Vancomycin-resistant Enterococci (VRE) have the ability to substitute D-lactate to the D-alanine terminus because of a modification in the cell wall peptide sequence. This modification makes the cell wall less susceptible to vancomycin binding, leading to the development of resistance to vancomycin. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking for the mechanism that best explains the increased incidence of vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus fecalis infections. Among the options, the replacement of the terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan by D-lactate is the mechanism that confers resistance to vancomycin. Qnr protein protects the antibiotic-binding site of quinolones, efflux pumps extrude antibiotics from the bacterial cell, and decreased number of porins lead to decreased intracellular entry of the antibiotic have no relation to vancomycin resistance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis in bacteria, and vancomycin-resistant bacteria may modify or replace the target cell wall structures. The replacement of the terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan by D-lactate is a known mechanism of resistance in Enterococcus fecalis. The other options are mechanisms of resistance in other types of bacteria or antibiotics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin targets the terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan of bacteria, and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus fecalis infections occur due to the replacement of the terminal D-ala by D-lactate. None of the other options explain this mechanism. Qnr protein protects the antibiotic-binding site of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV against quinolones, Efflux pumps extrude the antibiotic from the bacterial cell, and decreased number of porins in the bacterial cell wall leading to decreased intracellular entry of the antibiotic are mechanisms for resistance to other antibiotics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Enterococcus faecalis is known for its ability to develop resistance to antibiotics, including vancomycin. One of the mechanisms of resistance is the substitution of a terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan by D-lactate, which prevents vancomycin from binding to the cell wall. This mechanism is often called the VanA type of resistance. Protection of the antibiotic-binding site by Qnr protein is a mechanism of fluoroquinolone resistance in bacteria. Increased expression of efflux pumps which extrude the antibiotic from the bacterial cell and decreased number of porins in the bacterial cell wall leading to decreased intracellular entry of the antibiotic are mechanisms of resistance to other groups of antibiotics, but not vancomycin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Enterococcus fecalis can develop resistance to vancomycin by replacing the terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan by D-lactate, which changes the target site for vancomycin. This mechanism is called VanA resistance, and it is the most common mechanism of vancomycin resistance in enterococci. The other options are not relevant to vancomycin resistance in enterococci, although they may apply to other bacteria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin targets the D-ala-D-ala terminus of peptidoglycan during cell wall synthesis, and vancomycin resistance can occur by replacing it with D-lactate. Proteins like Qnr protect the bacterial DNA from quinolones, not vancomycin. Efflux pumps affect antibiotic concentration within bacterial cells and porins affect the entry of antibiotics from the outside, but they do not affect vancomycin's binding site in the bacterial cell wall.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin acts by inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis in bacterial cell walls, and resistance to vancomycin usually involves changes in the structure of the peptidoglycan. Replacement of the terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan by D-lactate is the mechanism of resistance seen in vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus fecalis. The other options are mechanisms of resistance to other antibiotics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin works by inhibiting cell wall biosynthesis by binding to terminal D-ala-D-ala residues. Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus fecalis have replaced the terminal D-ala with D-lactate, decreasing the affinity of vancomycin for the cell wall. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Option (A) refers to a mechanism of resistance for quinolone antibiotics, option (C) refers to a mechanism of resistance for tetracycline antibiotics, and option (D) refers to a mechanism of resistance for carbapenem antibiotics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus fecalis (VRE) has been known to result from replacement of the terminal D-ala in the cell wall peptidoglycan by D-lactate, which makes the bacteria resistant to vancomycin. A, C, and D are mechanisms of antibiotic resistance for other types of bacteria, but not VRE.
